Sure, Children in Need has a strong record of partnering with local communities in their interventions to mitigate the impact of political and social instability on vulnerable children. Here are some specific examples:

1. In Syria, Children in Need works in partnership with local organizations to provide psychosocial support, education, and healthcare services to Syrian refugee children. They also work with communities to promote child protection and safe spaces for children affected by the crisis.

2. In Somalia, Children in Need partners with community-based organizations to promote the rights of children and enable them to access education. They have established child-friendly spaces in the country to provide a safe environment for children affected by conflict, drought, and displacement.

3. In Yemen, Children in Need works closely with local organizations to deliver humanitarian assistance to children affected by the ongoing conflict. They provide food, healthcare, and psychosocial support to children living in camps and informal settlements.

4. In Bangladesh, Children in Need works with local volunteers to deliver aid and protection to Rohingya refugee children who have fled violence and persecution in Myanmar. They provide education, healthcare, and psychosocial support, as well as working with communities to promote the rights of children.

In each of these cases, Children in Need's partnership with local communities is critical to the success of their interventions. By involving local communities, they can better understand the specific needs of vulnerable children and work with them to deliver effective and sustainable support. This approach also helps to build the capacity of local organizations, empowering them to respond to future crises and promote the well-being of children in their communities.
